awd_titl_txt: Finding hydrothermal chimneys along the southern East Pacific Rise with machine learning approaches to AUV-based sonar data
awd_abstract_narration:
Seafloor hydrothermal systems emit hot, mineral- and microbial-rich fluids that impact seawater chemistry, with ramifications for everything from climate change to biomedical sciences. One of the most detailed and comprehensive plume surveys ever will be conducted on the South-East Pacific Rise. This research cruise will characterize both diffuse and focused hydrothermal discharge along a 300+ km length of the mid-ocean ridge. Based on sonar and photomosaic data resolving features to well under a meter in size, a machine learning method will detect and characterize hydrothermal vents from autonomous underwater vehicle sonar mapping. This will establish a comprehensive inventory of vent chimneys and hydrothermal sites, as well as examine changes in this system since its initial study about 24 years ago. Workflows for automated detection of possible hydrothermal chimneys from sub-meter gridded sonar data would enhance the infrastructure for all users of deep-submergence mapping sonars since searching for hydrothermal vents is a common use of these instruments. The study will implement a front-end Graphic User Interface that will be made available to anyone with basic skills in Geographic Information Systems to use. In order to make the experience of seafloor mapping available to an even broader community, a virtual fieldtrip, “Hunting Deep-Sea Hydrothermal Vents”, will be produced and expose students and the public to a rarely observed yet very critical environment for both geology and biodiversity. The project also will train a PhD student contributing to the next generation of marine geoscientists.

The central hypothesis of the research is that hydrothermal chimney distributions correlate with observable geologic features, and that those correlations will provide important insights into the causes of variations in hydrothermal flux, longevity, and chimney distribution from the ridge segment to global scales. This project plans to collect sonar data and photomosaics over hydrothermal vent fields along the Southern East Pacific Rise from ~15°-18°S. These data would be used to develop a machine-learning method to detect and characterize hydrothermal vents from sub-meter scale sonar maps. The development and application of machine learning to find hydrothermal vents will assist in detecting changes after almost 24 years in both in volcanic-tectonic morphology as well as hydrothermal vent fields at a ridge where the magmatic recurrence interval is thought to be approximately 7 years long. A user-friendly interface to the machine learning algorithm, implemented in Python, would enable non-experts to map candidate hydrothermal chimneys from bathymetric data to assist in more efficient dive planning and/or identification of targets for further investigation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we used an autonomous underwater robot called Sentry to explore close to the seafloor along a seafloor spreading ridge in the South Pacific to look for new volcanic eruptions and new types of underwater hot springs, hydrothermal vents, that could be important in regulating the chemical composition of Earth's oceans. Seafloor hydrothermal vents emit hot, mineral- and microbial-rich fluids that affect seawater chemistry. This project has developed a comprehensive inventory of vent chimneys and hydrothermal sites, as well as documented changes in this system since its initial study over 25 years ago. Very little is known about mid-ocean ridge processes on decadal timescales except at a couple of sites with repeated visits, and both of these site are relatively short (~20 km) segments of ridge. During 2021, we used Sentry to collect seafloor photos and side-scan sonar images along the Southern East Pacific Rise crest to characterize both diffuse and focused hydrothermal discharge along a 150 km length of the mid-ocean ridge. Previous studies in 1996 similarly collected seafloor video and side-scan sonar over a 100 km long coincident length of ridge. This yields one of the longest records of changes at a spreading ridge both spatially and temporally, and where the spreading has added 3+ m of new seafloor.

 Based on sonar and photographic data that resolve features well under a meter in size, a machine learning method was developed to detect and characterize hydrothermal vents from autonomous underwater vehicle sonar mapping. We developed the “Chimney Identification Tool” that utilizes a convolutional neural network to classify 1 m gridded bathymetry to identify the locations of hydrothermal vent chimneys. This is the first fully automated chimney identification algorithm, with the consequent advance of being available for non-expert users to identify possible hydrothermal vents in an efficient and replicable way in any comparable datasets. The Chimney Identification Tool was also used to identify hydrothermal chimneys off-axis around the East Pacific Rise near 9 50’N, along the axis of the Galapagos Spreading Center near 92W, and on Endeavor segment of Juan de Fuca Ridge.

The new complete catalog of hydrothermal chimneys for the Southern East Pacific Rise collected in 2021 shows new locations and patterns of hydrothermal activity compared to previous surveys conducted about two decades earlier. We were able to compare the locations of the hydrothermal vent chimneys to plumes of hydrothermal fluid detected in the water column, using the low-flying Sentry to collect data to collect both datasets simultaneously. Comparing the datasests suggests that the hydrothermal activity at the Southern East Pacific Rise has steadily decreased since the early 1990’s. However, we also found many more sources of low-temperature hydrothermal flow than expected. Sentry detected 44 anomalies indicating hydrothermal discharge, of which 31 were previously unknown low-temperature hydrothermal vents. Over 90% of these anomalies were found within 50 m of fissures identified using the side-scan sonar. This supports the idea that on the local scale permeability provided by distinct subsurface flow pathways controls where vents form.

 A new eruption was found at the Southern East Pacific Rise at 17 45’N. No new eruptions were found elsewhere in spite of >3 m of theoretical seafloor spreading at this place along the ridge since the last comprehensive survey in 1996. Our resurvey adds a significant new piece to the puzzle of how often volcanic eruptions can be expected at mid-ocean ridges. Ages for lava flows on the 10-100 year timescale notoriously difficult to determine, but this new data gives us a direct, observational comparison. What appears to be true based on the evidence based on our new observations and seafloor mapping is that eruptions occur at highly irregular intervals through time, where eruptive episodes are separated by long periods of inactivity on decadal timescales. This is a very significant finding because it is backed by direct, repeated observation and other studies of eruption processes at mid-ocean ridges need to account for both periods of quiesence lasting decades and periods of magmatic flare-ups.
